image.altText: A woman takes a photo from a boat of an erupting volcano

items.synopsis: The Whakaari White Island trial hears from experts that a shipping container placed on the volcano "as a shelter" was of little value in the event of an eruption.

title.children: Shipping container was of 'little effective value' as shelter during eruption, court hears

image.altText: Three women and survivors of sexual abuse stand on a flight of stairs leading to the Maroochydore District Court.

items.synopsis: Four survivors of sexual abuse have told their story about a Sunshine Coast man who sexually assaulted them as children and how it severely impacted every aspect of their lives.

title.children: Decades after their abuse ended, four women unite to jail a paedophile

image.altText: A man in a dark navy suit and pink tie speaks in parliament, with an Indigenous female minister sitting behind, watching on

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has claimed surveys show Indigenous Australians support the Voice at a rate between 80 and 90 per cent. Is that correct? RMIT ABC Fact Check investigates.

title.children: Fact check: Do the polls show that Indigenous support for the Voice is between 80 and 90 per cent?

image.altText: Australia playing Malawi at the Netball World Cup.

items.synopsis: South Africa has taken great pride in hosting its first major netball tournament, but World Cup organisers have stunted the event's potential with a number of failures, writes Brittany Carter.

title.children: Netball World Cup marred by ticketing issues, theft and poor organisation

image.altText: A young woman wearing a white winter coat sitting by a river, looking into the distance.

items.synopsis: Angela Williams only took part in one bodybuilding competition, but says the experience left her with years of health issues. She is one of several current and ex-competitors concerned about the strict dieting in the industry.

title.children: 'Glitzy' photos of bodybuilders on stage made Angela want to join them. She didn't see the health risks

image.altText: Unidentified child drawing.

items.synopsis: Gaye was sexually abused when she was a young child. Warning signs at the time were ignored or brushed under the carpet and when her fragments of memories of the abuse came together years later, she found she was still being "silenced".

title.children: Five-year-old Gaye drew men differently to other kids. Her drawings held a sinister revelation

image.altText: Five pieces of paper are displayed overlapping each other, all pages of an indictment against Donald Trump, outlining charges

items.synopsis: Donald Trump has been formally indicted for a third time, over alleged attempts to overturn the 2020 presidential election that culminated in the January 6 insurrection. Here's what we know so far.

title.children: Trump's legal woes are stacking up. Here's what we know about his third indictment

image.altText: Donald Trump pictured making a fist while speaking into microphone at podium with US flag in background.

items.synopsis: Former US president Donald Trump has been indicted on four charges related to attempts to overturn the 2020 US presidential election.

title.children: Trump faces charges including conspiracy to defraud US, obstruction of official proceeding

image.altText: Luc sits on a purple couch wearing a black t-shirt and jeans and holding a basketball.

items.synopsis: A new documentary celebrating Luc Longley's three consecutive NBA championships, and featuring exclusive new footage from The Last Dance, will offer a fascinating insight into the Australian basketball legend.

title.children: After The Last Dance overlooked his contributions to the Chicago Bulls, this NBA doco is shining a light on Luc Longley

image.altText: A television studio is seen through glass windows underneath an ABC News logo.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: ABC reverses decision to scrap local 7pm Sunday news bulletins — the latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says his government is taking steps to look at any gaps in child protection regulations, after the shocking arrest of a childcare worker who allegedly raped and abused 91 girls over a 15 year period. The 45-year-old Gold Coast man is facing hundreds of charges over the abuse, which allegedly occured in Brisbane, Sydney and overseas between 2007 and 2022. The allegations have raised questions about the strength and suitability of background checks for people working with children. Minns has told parliament the situation is every parent's worst nightmare and he's determined to make sure there is better information sharing between jurisdictions.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shock child abuse charges prompt NSW child protection review

children.content: (ABC News: Keana Naughton)
New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says his government is taking steps to look at any gaps in child protection regulations, after the shocking arrest of a childcare worker who allegedly
raped and abused 91 girls over a 15 year period.
The 45-year-old Gold Coast man is facing hundreds of charges over the abuse, which allegedly occured in Brisbane, Sydney and overseas between 2007 and 2022.
The allegations have raised questions about the strength and suitability of background checks for people working with children.
Minns has told parliament the situation is every parent's worst nightmare and he's determined to make sure there is better information sharing between jurisdictions.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australians on income support payments will receive $56 extra a fortnight from September, after federal government changes passed through parliament. The government committed to raising Jobseeker by $40 in May's federal budget, but that figure has increased to $56 due to indexation. As AAP reports, other changes which have been passed include: The age at which the higher rate of JobSeeker for single recipients is paid will be reduced from 60 to 55 for those who have been on payment for nine continuous months Commonwealth Rent Assistance maximum rates will increase by 15 per cent, with about 1.1 million households better off by, on average, $24 per fortnight About 57,000 single parents (90 per cent of whom are single mothers) with children aged eight and above will be eligible for the higher Parenting Payment (Single), adding at least $176.90 per fortnight to the support they receive until their youngest child turns 14
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Extra welfare supports have just passed parliament

children.content: Australians on income support payments will receive $56 extra a fortnight from September
, after federal government changes passed through parliament.
The government committed to raising Jobseeker by $40 in May's federal budget, but that figure has increased to $56 due to indexation.
As AAP reports, other changes which have been passed include:
The age at which the higher rate of JobSeeker for single recipients is paid will be reduced from 60 to 55 for those who have been on payment for nine continuous months
Commonwealth Rent Assistance maximum rates will increase by 15 per cent, with about 1.1 million households better off by, on average, $24 per fortnight

About 57,000 single parents (90 per cent of whom are single mothers) with children aged eight and above will be eligible for the higher Parenting Payment (Single), adding at least $176.90 per fortnight to the support they receive until their youngest child turns 14

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Supermarket giant Woolworths has been accused of under-paying former employees more than $1 milion in long-service leave. Wage Inspectorate Victoria has filed more than 1,000 charges against Woolworths Group, alleging it failed to pay 1,235 former Victorian employees between 2018 and 2021. Alleged underpayments ranged from $250 to more than $12,000. The matter will be heard in Melbourne Magistrates court in September and the ABC has contacted the organisation for comment. Reporting by Lexie Jeuniewic
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Woolworths accused of underpaying employees in long-service leave

props.alt: The Woolworths logo, with the words 'the fresh food people'

children.content: (ABC News)
Supermarket giant Woolworths has been
accused of under-paying former employees more than $1 milion
in long-service leave.
Wage Inspectorate Victoria has filed more than 1,000 charges against Woolworths Group,
alleging it failed to pay 1,235 former Victorian employees
between 2018 and 2021.
Alleged underpayments ranged from $250 to more than $12,000.
The matter will be heard in Melbourne Magistrates court in September and the ABC has contacted the organisation for comment.
Reporting by Lexie Jeuniewic

image.altText: A large concrete sign with letters saying National Gallery of Australia.

items.synopsis: The National Gallery of Australia says its independent review into controversial artworks from South Australia's APY Lands has cleared the works of improper interference, but said how the art collective operates was a matter for the SA government, which is running a separate inquiry.

title.children: National Gallery's independent review finds in favour of APY artists

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A composite image of Denmark's Sanne Troelsgaard and Australia's  Alanna Kennedy and Katrina Gorry celebrating

items.synopsis: The results from this week's matches mean the Aussies will be playing Denmark on Monday — and they'll be hitting the field in their yellow jerseys.

title.children: Matildas to take on Denmark next at Women's World Cup

image.altText: A Portuguese striker, an American defender and goalkeeper go flying as the ball cannons off the post in a match.

items.synopsis: Defending champion the United States stays alive in the Women's World Cup by the width of a post, England's Lauren James destroys China's hopes, and a false fire alarm interrupts play in Auckland. These are the five talking points from last night.

title.children: Five quick hits — United States survives by width of the post, fire alarm stops play, Lauren James stars for England

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Australian dollar has slumped nearly 2 per cent and global markets have been hit by a downgrade of the US credit rating. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Markets in red as US loses AAA credit rating over debt limit stand-offs, Australian dollar slumps

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More detail from the Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on how higher prices are hurting households. Employee households were most affected by rising mortgage interest charges, but higher prices for food, insurance, utilities, and housing increased the cost of living for everyone. The ABS says living costs for employee households rose 1.5 per cent over the June quarter, the largest increase of all household types. Over the year, living costs for employee households increased by 9.6 per cent, the most on record. Insurance premiums rose across house, house contents, and car insurance. Eating out, takeaway food, and fruit and vegetables increased, as did strong demand for rental properties which drove rents higher. The ABS' Living Cost Indexes includes mortgage interest charges, while the Consumer Price Index measures the cost of new dwellings. It says increasing interest rates saw the cost of living rise from between 6.3 per cent to 9.6 per cent, higher than the 6 per cent annual increase in the CPI. Mortgage interest charges rose by 91.6 per cent over the year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Higher mortgage repayments push up living costs

children.content: More detail from the Bureau of Statistics (ABS) on how higher prices are hurting households.
Employee households were most affected by rising mortgage interest charges, but higher prices for food, insurance, utilities, and housing increased the cost of living for everyone.
The ABS says living costs for employee households rose 1.5 per cent over the June quarter, the largest increase of all household types.

props.alt: table showing cost of living for households

children.content: Cost of living
(ABS)
Over the year, living costs for employee households increased by 9.6 per cent, the most on record.
Insurance premiums rose across house, house contents, and car insurance.
Eating out, takeaway food, and fruit and vegetables increased, as did strong demand for rental properties which drove rents higher.
The ABS' Living Cost Indexes includes mortgage interest charges, while the Consumer Price Index measures the cost of new dwellings.
It says increasing interest rates saw the cost of living rise from between 6.3 per cent to 9.6 per cent, higher than the 6 per cent annual increase in the CPI.
Mortgage interest charges rose by 91.6 per cent over the year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A record 947,300 Australians are working multiple jobs, according to the latest estimates from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That compares to just over 13 million Australians who only hold one job, meaning that 6.6% of all workers are holding down multiple positions. Before COVID, the proportion of workers doing multiple jobs was fairly steady between 5-6%, but has remained above that level since December 2021. On average, multiple job holders worked longer hours than those with only one position. The average multiple job holder worked 30.9 hours a week in their main job and 9.6 hours in their secondary one, for a total of 40.5 hours — above a standard working week. Single job holders worked 35.5 hours per week on average. Men with multiple jobs worked the longest hours, on average, at 45.3, women with multiple jobs worked an average of 36.4 hours a week in paid employment. Women were more likely to hold multiple jobs (7.7%) than men (5.7%). Those aged 20-24 were most likely to hold more than one job (8.9%), while 7.9% of employed 15-19-year-olds also held more than one job. Only 5.5% of employed people aged 60-64 and 5.2% of those working aged 65 or older worked more than one job. Those working in agriculture, forestry and fishing, administrative and support services, arts and recreation, accommodation and food services, healthcare and social assistance, and education and training had the highest rates of multiple job holding (all above 7%). Those employed by utilities, financial and insurance firms, wholesalers, manufacturers and logistics firms were the least likely to hold multiple jobs (less than 5%).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Record number of Australians working multiple jobs

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some. Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China. The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out that is just 3 per cent from its record high. Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade. Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market. Top movers on ASX 200: BrainChip: +4% Pro Medicus: +2.6% Domino's Pizza: +2.1% Regis Resources: -4.3% AGL Energy: -4.1% Champion Iron: -3.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

children.content: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some.
Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China.
The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out that is just 3 per cent from its record high.
Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade.
Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market.
Top movers on ASX 200:
BrainChip: +4%
Pro Medicus: +2.6%
Domino's Pizza: +2.1%
Regis Resources: -4.3%
AGL Energy: -4.1%
Champion Iron: -3.6%

image.altText: A woman watches on during a national swimming trial

items.synopsis: The WA Supreme Court hears Bianca Rinehart labelled her brother 'idiot John' in an email forwarded to her mother which contained details of John's attempts to have her removed from the family trust.

title.children: Court hears emails between Gina Rinehart's children discussing removing her from family trust

image.altText: A smiling Australian swimmer stands on the pooldeck with a gold medal around his neck after his event.

items.synopsis: Australia win another five medals, including three gold, on the second night at the Para Swimming World Championships in Manchester.

title.children: Golden night for Aussies at Para Swimming World Championships

image.altText: A close-up of a golden lion tamarin monkey looking at the camera.

items.synopsis: Once on the brink of extinction with only about 200 animals in the wild, the golden lion tamarin population has rebounded to around 4,800 individuals hopping between branches in the Brazilian rainforest.

title.children: 'We are celebrating': Vaccines help Brazil's golden monkeys rebound from near extinction

image.altText: black and white image of spotted western quoll

items.synopsis: The tiny, native western quoll that was all but wiped out in Western Australia has been reintroduced to parts of the state, and this time their welfare is being watched over by drones.

title.children: This native species disappeared 100 years ago, but ecologists are bringing them back from the brink

image.altText: Woman holding two-year-old boy wearing a green jumper stands at a gate outside a house, smiling.

items.synopsis: It's a long way from anywhere, but Thargomindah in outback Queensland — population 243 — goes to extraordinary lengths to ensure residents don't desert the town.

title.children: Welcome to the outback town where residents are renting to buy their homes

image.altText: The exterior of the High Court of Australia in Canberra

items.synopsis: The High Court of Australia ruled the land at Ponde was invalidly prescribed, and the pair were denied procedural fairness and should have been given notice of the declaration.

title.children: Hells Angels members win High Court of Australia battle with SA government

image.altText: An Australian Federal Police badge

items.synopsis: The ABC has confirmed that one of the man's employers was a childcare centre associated with a tertiary facility.

title.children: Former childcare worker charged with sex offences was known as 'unofficial photographer' at one facility

image.altText: Two loafs of gluten free sour dough

items.synopsis: Global wheat prices are rising sharply after a UN-brokered deal to ship grain out of Ukraine ended last month, with Australian farmers set to benefit but consumers, especially in some of the world's poorest countries, to pay the price.

title.children: 'Prices are definitely going to be higher': How Russia's latest actions may lift the cost of a loaf of bread

image.altText: Long grass surrounds a yellow sign post

items.synopsis: Poland's defence ministry says it sent "additional forces and resources, including combat helicopters" to its eastern border.

title.children: Poland sends troops to Belarus border fearing airspace violations

items.synopsis: A zoo in eastern China is denying suggestions one of its bears might be a staff member in a costume as images of the animal standing like a human circulate online.

title.children: 'If this is fake it deserves an Oscar': Tourists flock to Chinese zoo as claims of staff in bear suit spread

image.altText: Henrietta Lacks' cell line has been widely used by the biomedical industry.

items.synopsis: Henrietta Lacks's tissue was harvested without her permission and used to make millions of dollars. Now her descendants have reached a settlement with a biotech company they say has profited from a racist medical system.

title.children: US woman's family settles lawsuit with biotech company that used her cells without consent

image.altText: A man in a suit on a laptop searching real estate websites.

image.altText: Close up of Nicole Asher

image.altText: A man, holding his hands atop his head, and a woman looking down, arriving at an airport

title.children: Evacuations begin in Niger as neighbouring countries warn of war

image.altText: A large, full red moon behind a cathedral

items.synopsis: From country to country, keen sky gazers diligently capture the sturgeon Moon — the first of two supermoons in August.

title.children: Sturgeon supermoon illuminates night skies around the world
